I don't think it's not using the algebra that gets people to these payday places. The other way those places rake in the dough, is cashing paychecks for people who cannot open a bank account. They charge a hefty fee for the pleasure, I mean privilege, of cashing a paycheck. Places like Walmart also cash paychecks for people, for a lot less. Walmart and American Express are in partnership in a reloadable debit card called Bluebird...

All of these outfits should be regulated with the banks, under the same rules. It's shameful.

Have recently read a classic paper by Robert Jackall entitled "Moral Mazes: Bureaucracy and Managerial Work". The paper talks about the realities of operations and advancement in large US corporations. (BTW, I urge anyone who thinks of American business as a meritocracy to read this paper.) About blame, Jackall writes:

"For managers, blame -- like failure -- has nothing to do with the merits of a case; it is a matter of social definition. As a general rule, it is those who are or who become politically vulnerable or expendable who get 'set up' and become blameable. The most feared situation of all is to end up in the wrong place at the wrong time."

What is true for the managerial class is indisputably also true for the political class. Objective truth is only a tiny part of the story. As long as the Ryans of the world deliver the results their actual bosses want -- low taxes and continued license to exploit -- their objective failures will forever be painted as theoretically correct policies that were frustrated by mysterious, inimical forces. Only by tweeting pictures of his male anatomy or similarly stupid act would a Ryan ever get called to actually account for their positions.

Kurt, it's interesting that your response to a problem of tremendous waste is NOT to address the waste, but instead imply that we should simply waste more land to grow uneaten food.

I've seen windfarms as I fly around and they really don't take up much space in midwestern farmland. And I don't see a lot of planting on mountain ridges, or out at sea.

But mountaintop-removal coal mining, tar sands mining and fracking sites take up land, too. All energy takes up land.

There's also a lot of innovation going on now that wind energy is being implemented (as always happens - the initial gasoline engine was nowhere near as efficient as ones built today). This experiment is looking to create denser patterns of vertical turbines that actually share the breeze.
http://www.caltech.edu/content/schooling-fish-offer-new-ideas-wind-farming

More energy from less space, and safer for workers (no need to climb tall turbines) and possibly for birds (smaller, lower rotors).

How much arable land is taken up by solar panels if they are placed on top of the existing big, flat roofs of WalMart stores? They're planning to take their stores off the grid, and much of the plan is based on the fact that the sun shines on buildings as well as on fields.

Energy storage is also seeing strong innovation, so we should be able to extract more useful renewable energy as individual production sites are smoothed with battery or water storage.

b fagan,

Of course I think that waste needs to be addressed. My response was in passing.

I am currently in the USA. I drove the PA Turnpike yesterday, where I saw multiple small solar farms occupying obviously arable land. Obviously somebody thinks this is a good thing. Germany has also taken similar measures. This is due to ill-advised incentives which make it more lucrative for a farmer to have solar panels installed vs. growing crops. Likewise, turning corn into ethanol to power vehicles will reduce the food produced and contribute to the increase in food prices (hurting the poorest people the hardest).

Solar PV on buildings can make sense, however. These need to be evaluated on a case-by-case basis. Too often, the public hand blindly funds projects which never actually show a return on investment.

I applaud improvements in wind energy technology and support its use if the macro studies justify the same. But the explosion in wind turbine installations is causing multiple problems:

- noise vibration disturbance for those living working nearby
- deaths to birds and bats
- aesthetic footprint
- absent battery technology, creation of power gaps and spikes
- absent smart grid / new lines, power bottlenecks
- drainage problems (foundation of deep cement required for towers)
- removal costs (including return to original state) can be prohibitive.

Kurt in Switzerland

Kurt, I'm glad we have some common ground.

We're feeling our way too slowly into the renewable market, and some of the moves are plainly boneheaded - like the ethanol fixed requirements in gasoline. The reference you posted recently about the German who is against all this change seemed to be more realistically an indictment of Germany's decision to phase out a lot of nuclear before working in the proper replacement - also (in my opinion) a boneheaded move.

But we're warming the planet, and effects will be unpredictable - which usually means "more expensive than we thought". I've seen nothing published that indicates that increases in the persistent greenhouse gases will somehow NOT lead to increased greenhouse warming.

So, I think we should do the following:
1 - go after the efficiency issues aggressively - cut down waste in everything. Insulate and seal residences, manage power in larger buildings, continue with CAFE and EnergyStar -type regulations to drive manufacturers of consumer products.

2 - put a price on carbon. Cap and trade worked here for sulfur emissions. Price it and let the market help out.

3 - push energy storage R&D aggressively. There's a lot of interesting work that could minimize changes to our very messy grid with its >500 owners.

As to the aesthetic qualities of turbines, I grew up near what was then the Esso/Exxon Bayway Refinery, and near the lovely petroleum storage facilities along the Arthur Kill. I'll take turbines!

Absolutely. In an attempt to remove stigma from overweight, normal weight is described as "thin", and that in turn is depicted to embody pathology.

People of any weight can have an eating disorder, depending on the particulars (like, if purging is involved). Physicians and parents should *always* bear in mind that possibility.

Excessive weight-loss is only one form of eating disorder. To use the phrase "eating disorder" as though it were a synonym for excessive weight-loss is, once again, to shunt to the sidelines of care those people, including plenty of adolescents, who suffer from compulsive overeating and from various forms of binge-eating disorder.

I am the primary breadwinner in my family. My job pays for our house, our food, provides with health insurance and enough to save for retirement and for to put money away in a 529 plan for both daughters. My husband works part time and seasonally, and in the summer as a wildlife biologist, sometimes out of state. His schedule is completely unpredictable and not conducive to taking care of small children. It's not about "having a lifestyle", it's about being adults who are working and providing for our children.

Our daycare providers - at a center - have health insurance, sick time and vacation days, but it is not possible to pay them more than what I make. They should make what I do; I am a middle school teacher at a public school, and have taught their children. They just happen to be working with younger people.

As a mental health practician (psychiatrist), I can vouch that many of my most vulnerable patients' primary stressor is housing insecurity. The need to maintain housing then leads to vulnerabilities in food security, energy security, health security, educational security, et cetera. If you receive a disability stipend of $780 and pay $300 a month for the rattiest of housing, and even with other safety net interventions (which are rapidly being cut) like SNAP, energy supports and others, the least unexpected item (doctor's bill, medications, car bill, shoes) can lead to the need for immediate credit. Never mind the terms, these are needs that are both immediate and essential, hence the need for payday loans. So while banks can rely on overnight discount rates supported by the FED the rest of us suffer when it comes to liquid credit. The poor/working poor rely on payday loans, the middle class on credit cards and home equity, but neither are on terms anywhere as favorable as those received by our financial institutions who pay their senior management billions in salaries and bonuses.

Truncated to fit word limit:

What's the Matter with Kansas?: How Conservatives Won the Heart of America by Thomas Frank
New York Times bestseller, praised as "hilariously funny . . .understand why so many Americans have decided to vote against their own economic and political interests" (Molly Ivins)

"dazzlingly insightful and wonderfully sardonic" (Chicago Tribune), "very funny and very painful" (San Francisco Chronicle), and "in a different league from most political books" (The New York Observer), unravels the great political mystery of our day: Why do so many Americans vote against their economic and social interests? With his acclaimed wit and acuity, Thomas Frank answers the riddle by examining his home state, Kansas-a place once famous for its radicalism that now ranks among the nation's most eager participants in the culture wars. Charting what he calls the "thirty-year backlash"-the popular revolt against a supposedly liberal establishment-Frank reveals how conservatism, once a marker of class privilege, became the creed of millions of ordinary Americans.

A brilliant analysis-and funny to boot- is a vivid portrait of an upside-down world where blue-collar patriots recite the Pledge while they strangle their life chances; where small farmers cast their votes for a Wall Street order that will eventually push them off their land; and where a group of frat boys, lawyers, and CEOs has managed to convince the country that it speaks on behalf of the People.

Furthermore, a moneyed, arrogant, stubborn minority has been allowed to take the reins on an issue about which most of us feel extremely angry and disgusted -- like you do, but much worse. Just read these comments... and hope for our country that we can finally force our legislators to defeat the gun lobby and take meaningful action across the board.
